717273f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Houston Street (East)
717273f-a.text:
Broadway, north from but not including East Houston Street, showing horse
dfawn public coachs on Broadway, and a simularly drawn street car on
Bleeker Street. The gas lamps shown in the foreground, at the curb, are
in front of the Olympic Theatre, which is on the east side, between East
Houston and Bleeker Streets.
Ewing Galloway  1865
N.; ~ 287.

717269f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Houston Street
717269f-a.text:
Broadway, north from a point slightly south of Houston Street, showing
vehicular and pedestrian traffic on this main artery of Manhattan during
a spectacular period in the Citys history. Note the paved condition
of the street bed and the lack of mechanical transportation; gas street
lamps appearing midst overhead wire commnnications. The Grand Central
Hotel which became the present Broadway Central Hotel is in the mid-
distance with Grace P.E. Church farther northward, at the bend. The
structures in the foreground, (both right and left sides) have disappeared
today, vacant lots being tnereon, caused by demolition work during
construction of the Independent Subway. This photograph, made from
one of the early dry plates, comes from a book entitled "How to make
photographs" by T.C. Roche.
1883.
NN. Nc :

717271f.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Houston Street (West)
717271f.text:
Broadway, west side, at West Houston Street, as viewed in a northward
direction and showing prominently the Cable Building at the N.W. corner
of both streets. The three buildings shown on the left are Nos. 605-
607 (5-story Austin Building); No. 603, (8-story structure) and No. 601
(2-story structure). These were demolished in 1933 as a part of the
Eighth Ave. Subway construction.
May 25, 1904.
Brown Brothers.

717275f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Houston Street (West)
717275f-a.text:
621-633 Broadway, at adjoining and north of the N.W. corner of West
Houston Street, as seen across the clearance at the N.E. corner, caused by
the Eighth Ave. subway construction.
February 21, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

717274f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Houston Street
717274f-a.text:
Broadway, north across Houston Street, showing prominently
the easterly side of this thorughfare. Note the Olympic Thea.
tre at No. 622. This was demolished about 1880. In the beck-
ground, at the bend at 10th Street, is Grace P.E. Church.
Prior to 1880
Gift or Urbrock Collection

719450f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - Broadway
719450f-a.text:
East Houston Street, at the S.E. corner of Broadway, showing the
6-story Holt Building being rased. The entire block of buildings of
which this one is a part were later demolished to make room for the
construction of the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway).
September 26, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

724489f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (West - Broadway
724489f-a.text:
1-9 West Houston Street and b05-oCv Broadway, at the S.W. corner,
a brick office building faced with iron. It probably dates
from the 1870's.
September 19, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

724491f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (West - Broadway
724491f-a.text:
Houston Street, south side, west from Broadway, just before the
demolition of the entire south side west to Sixth Avenue.
September 19, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
